**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u202f28**.proposition: 1. This is a Complaint for Modification brought pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209, § 37**, and **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, seeking modification of an existing custody and parenting-time order entered by this Court on **May 15, 2018** in the above-captioned matter.

**G.L. c. 209, \u00a7\u202f37**.proposition: 1. This is a Complaint for Modification brought pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209, § 37**, and **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, seeking modification of an existing custody and parenting-time order entered by this Court on **May 15, 2018** in the above-captioned matter.

**G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u202f20**.proposition: 1. This is a Complaint for Modification brought pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209, § 37**, and **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, seeking modification of an existing custody and parenting-time order entered by this Court on **May 15, 2018** in the above-captioned matter.

**G.L. c.\u202f208, \u00a7\u202f31**.proposition: 7. Since the entry of the Existing Order, there has been a **substantial and material change in circumstances** affecting the welfare of the minor child within the meaning of **G.L. c. 208, § 28** and **G.L. c. 208, § 31**, rendering modification necessary and proper.

**G.L. c.\u202f215, \u00a7\u202f6**.proposition: - **G.L. c. 215, § 6** (probate court jurisdiction over custody matters);

**G.L. c.\u202f208, \u00a7\u202f29**.proposition: - **G.L. c. 208, § 29** (enforcement and modification of family law decrees).

*G.L. c.\u202f208, \u00a7\u202f34*.proposition: 12. Massachusetts case law consistently requires that modification be based on post-judgment changes that affect the child’s welfare and best interests, including:

**G.L. c.\u202f208, \u00a7\u00a7\u202f28.proposition: 15. The proposed adjustment would foster a healthy, consistent relationship with both parents in compliance with the objectives of **G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31**, ensuring that the child maintains frequent and continuing contact with each parent who has demonstrated the ability to act in the child’s best interests.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: 9. These developments collectively constitute a **material change in circumstances** pursuant to the standards set forth in *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 1031 (2009); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: Yannas does not deal with whether certain post-judgment developments amount to a “material change in circumstances.” Instead, it articulates the removal/relocation standard (“real advantage”) and explains how to evaluate the best interests of the child and interests of the custodial and noncustodial parents when relocation is first sought. It neither defines nor applies the separate threshold requirement of a material change in circumstances for modification, so it does not support the proposition that particular developments constitute such a material change under Yannas, Schuh, and Custody of Kali.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin…; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 1031 (2009).proposition: 9. These developments collectively constitute a **material change in circumstances** pursuant to the standards set forth in *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 1031 (2009); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: 9. These developments collectively constitute a **material change in circumstances** pursuant to the standards set forth in *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 1031 (2009); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that Custody of Kali sets forth or applies the “material/substantial change in circumstances” standard (as in Yannas and Schuh) for modification, and that certain developments can collectively constitute such a change. In Kali, however, the SJC explicitly refuses to apply or discuss the substantial-change standard, holding that the case was tried under the initial custody ‘best interests’ standard of G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and that any § 20 modification argument was waived. The opinion therefore does not provide authority on what constitutes a material change in circumstances and cannot support that proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody order may be modified “upon a showing of changed circumstances and where modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.” *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman concerns standards for removal of children from Massachusetts under G.L. c. 208, § 30, in a joint physical custody context; it does not set out the general standard for modification of custody orders. The opinion briefly references modification procedurally, but the legal analysis and holding are about the meaning of “upon cause shown” in the removal statute, not about when custody may be modified “upon a showing of changed circumstances” and necessity for the child’s best interests. Thus, it does not support the quoted modification standard proposition.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ … ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985).”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody order may be modified “upon a showing of changed circumstances and where modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.” *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the governing standard for modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28 as requiring a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification be necessary in the child’s best interests. The court applies this standard to reverse the change in custody, making it clear that both prongs—changed circumstances and best interests—are required. This aligns with the proposition for which Rosenthal is cited alongside Mason v. Coleman.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: 12. Massachusetts case law consistently requires that modification be based on post-judgment changes that affect the child’s welfare and best interests, including:
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion in Hunter v. Rose concerns recognition of a California registered domestic partnership, determination of legal parentage, a best-interests custody determination, and an award of attorney’s fees. It does not address modification of prior custody or support judgments, nor does it discuss the requirement that modification be based on post‑judgment changes affecting the child’s welfare. Therefore it does not provide authority for the modification principle stated in the proposition.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child” ….’ … ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.”’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”

*Rogers v. Rogers*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 58.proposition: 12. Massachusetts case law consistently requires that modification be based on post-judgment changes that affect the child’s welfare and best interests, including:
*Rogers v. Rogers*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 58.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about confrontation rights, cross-examination, Bowden instructions, and closing argument in an assault prosecution. It does not involve domestic relations, child custody, or modification of family law judgments, nor does it discuss post-judgment changes affecting a child’s welfare or best interests. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about Massachusetts modification standards in child-related matters.
*Rogers v. Rogers*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 58.relevant_excerpt: The opinion contains no discussion of child custody, modification of judgments, or standards based on a child’s welfare or best interests; it is entirely focused on evidentiary and procedural issues in a criminal prosecution for assault with intent to rape.

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: 12. Massachusetts case law consistently requires that modification be based on post-judgment changes that affect the child’s welfare and best interests, including:
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion discusses custody, visitation, abuse prevention orders, and removal standards, but it does not address modification of prior custody or support judgments or the requirement that modifications be based on post-judgment changes affecting a child’s welfare. The only references to modification are procedural (e.g., potential future modification of visitation or removal), not a doctrinal statement about the legal standard for modification. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about Massachusetts modification law.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: Despite the judge’s decision documenting the father’s abuse of the mother and concluding that the father’s visitation with the child should be suspended, the judge did not terminate the father’s parental rights, and clearly left open the possibility of a modification of his order precluding visitation. In a case such as this, the father’s constitutional rights as a parent require that the judge considering a request for removal take into account the potential for the father to seek a resumption of visitation.

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: 12. Massachusetts case law consistently requires that modification be based on post-judgment changes that affect the child’s welfare and best interests, including:
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The case is a removal and child-support modification decision, not a general articulation of the standard for modification of custody or parenting arrangements. While it applies a ‘best interests of the children’ analysis in the context of removal, it does not discuss the general Massachusetts rule that post-judgment modification must be based on material post-judgment changes affecting the child’s welfare and best interests. The only explicit reference to modification is in the child support context, tied to statutory guidelines and the mother’s remarriage, not a broad doctrinal statement of the proposition cited.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “On July 10, 2012, the mother filed a complaint for modification alleging, as a change in circumstances, that she was to be married on August 3, 2012, to a resident of Danville, California. For this reason, the complaint sought removal of the minor children to California. … Sometime thereafter, the father filed his own complaint for modification, wherein he sought to (1) reduce his child support obligation … Based on those changes, including adding the new husband’s voluntary contributions … the judge reduced the father’s child support obligation….”

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.proposition: 12. Massachusetts case law consistently requires that modification be based on post-judgment changes that affect the child’s welfare and best interests, including:
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns standards for *modification* based on post-judgment changes affecting a child’s welfare. Hale v. Hale is not a modification case; it is an initial determination on a custodial parent’s request to remove children from the Commonwealth in a separate support action. The court discusses and refines the ‘best interests of the child’ standard (including the custodial parent’s well-being) for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, but does not address the requirement of post-judgment change as a predicate for modification.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ in the controlling statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, set forth in the margin, have been interpreted to permit removal if in the best interests of the child. Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). However, the criteria for determining such best interests have, as yet, not been established, and decisions of the trial court as to whether removal should be allowed have been upheld without much discussion.”
